info.name: PERLS
info.description: A collection of items to test PERLS Rest API

item.name: Learner State APIs

request.description: Retrieve a list of bookmarked content IDs (but not the content itself). This request can be paged by adding the `page` query param (e.g. `?page=1`).

header.value: AWSALBCORS=oy1zdngzakw5DngzgEiR3eaTe/14FapUKuAQ8PorIX8ngr17n3DW4oQeIZuoc8Qw5xVhveyVEL3wjSc0qk5IyCa5rEdlgpT7DooCYuW98ejljTNN/J841jhCUaJ9; Expires=Wed, 08 Sep 2021 20:50:44 GMT; Path=/; SameSite=None; Secure

request.description: Retrieve a list of followed tag IDs (but not the tag itself). This request can be paged by adding the `page` query param (e.g. `?page=1`).
Retrieve a list of completed content IDs (but not the content itself). This request can be paged by adding the `page` query param (e.g. `?page=1`).
Retrieve a list of recommended content IDs (but not the content itself). This request can be paged by adding the `page` query param (e.g. `?page=1`).

request.description:
The current learner states of a specified corpus item.</br>
Using `nid` as the parameter here will limit items returned to nodes. </br>
Using `tid` as the parameter here will limit items returned to taxonomy terms.</br>
Using `id` as the parameter will return any entity that matches that id regardless of entity type.

item.name: All states for multiple corpus items

request.description:
The current learner states of multiple corpus items with their nid separated by a pipe.</br>
Using `nid` as the parameter here will limit items returned to nodes. </br>
Using `tid` as the parameter here will limit items returned to taxonomy terms.</br>
Using `id` as the parameter will return any entity that matches that id regardless of entity type.
Adding `entity_type` parameter can be used with `id` to get entities of a certain type.

item.description: These APIs retrieve the current learner's state (i.e. the list of content items they have bookmarked, completed, recommended, etc.).

request.description:
Retrieves the groups where the current user has an active membership.

### Paging
This endpoint allows for paging with the `page` query parameter. Paging uses a 0-based index. For example, to request the second page, add `page=1` to the query parameters.

response.name: Groups for current user

header.value: languages:language_interface request_format theme url user.group_permissions user.permissions
config:views.view.group_index group:15 group_content:240 group_content_list group_list http_response page_manager_route_name:view.group_index.rest_export_1

request.description:
Retrieves the current user's membership record from the specified group. ### Response |Property|Description| |--------|-----------| |id |UUID for the membership entity.| |url |Canonical URL for the entity; not currently used for anything meaningful.| |name |The name of the membership record; this will almost always be the learner's name.| |created |The date the user joined the group.| |status |`open` - The user can leave the group.
`locked` - The user cannot leave the group.| |group |The group the user belongs to.| |user |The user record.| ### Response codes `404` - either the group does not exist **or** the user is not a member of the group; the response message will disambiguate why the membership record could not be found

response.name: Example response
response.body:

request.description:
Retrieves information about a group. ### Response | Property | Description | |----------|-------------| |id |The UUID for the group entity.| |gid |A secondary identifier for the group. This ID is used in the canonical URL for the group. But you should always use the `url` field below for generating a group URL.| |url |The URL to the group in the web interface.| |name |The name of the group.| |changed |The date the group was last updated (does not update for changes in content or members, only for changes in group metadata.| |description|The group description.| |image |An image representing the group.| |visibility|`public` - anybody can see the group
`private` - only users in the group can see it. Learner cannot leave private groups.| ### Response codes * `200` - the group exists * `404` - the group could not be found **or** the user does not have permission to see the group.

request.description:
Retrieve the groups open to the current user to join.

### Paging
This endpoint allows for paging with the `page` query parameter. Paging uses a 0-based index. For example, to request the second page, add `page=1` to the query parameters.

response.name: Open groups

header.value: languages:language_interface request_format theme url user.group_permissions user.permissions

request.description:
Add the current user to a group.

The response is a membership record containing information about the user's membership (such as the date it was created, the group that was joined, and the membership status.

### Membership status
* `open` - the user can leave the group whenever they want
* `locked` - the user may not leave the group

### Response codes
* `201` - the membership was created
* `403` - the user is not allowed to join the group
* `404` - the group was not found; this status code can be returned for a group that does exist, but the current user does not have permission to see it
* `409` - the user is already a member of the group

response.name: User already belongs to group

request.description:
Leave a group.

The response body will be empty if the membership record was destroyed successfully (see **Response codes**).

### Response codes
* `204` - the membership was destroyed
* `403` - the user is not allowed to leave the group (i.e. if the group is private)
* `404` - the group was not found **or** the user did not belong to the group; the response message will disambiguate why the user could not leave the group

response.name: User is not in group

request.description:
Retrieves the first 30 topics associated with the group and the 10 most recently updated content items within that topics.

**Note:** This endpoint is currently limited and can only return up to 30 topics (for performance reasons). There is a separate endpoint for searching all group content.

### Response
For each topic, the server returns:
* `name` - the name of the topic
* `url` - the url for retrieving more than the first 10 items
* `content` - the 10 most recently updated content items within the topic that belong to the group

" }, "description": "A brief guide to creating an Emergency Action Plan", "image": { "UUID": "1f445741-9ed9-414f-8a60-68239e502915", "name": "emergency-plan.jpg", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg?itok=RG84ODJ3", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg" }, "body": [ { "id": 262, "uuid": "3c8cf7f3-6494-41aa-8844-60ffb4a8dca4", "revision_id": 595, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583858101, "parent_id": "227", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

How to Get Started

\r\n\r\n

The best time to handle an emergency is before it ever takes place. Before you create your emergency action plan, you'll need to analyze your business and see what potential hazards you face. These can vary depending on the type of business and your location. Some emergency action plans will cover problems dealing with hazardous materials on hand, some will need to deal with issues stemming from older buildings that were built to a lower-standard safety code, and some will need to have strategies in place to prepare for natural disasters more likely in certain areas, such as hurricanes, earthquakes, and tornadoes.

\r\n\r\n

While many things will be different depending on the type of emergency you are preparing forwhat you do during a tornado or earthquake will be much different than what you do during a fire or workplace violence incident, for examplesome of the basic preparations will be similar for multiple problems. Always provide steps for getting people to safety, whether that means sheltering or evacuating them, and always have a clear and effective plan for communicating with everyone who could be affected.

\r\n\r\n

Be sure to investigate not just what hazards you may face and how to stay safe during them, but also what effects they will have afterward. This should reveal such considerations as what lost income and increased expenses could be caused by your business being shut down for various amounts of time, the effect of lost customers, the delay of new business plans, and other effects of a disruption of service. Be as exact as possible in order to get a good idea of what costs you might accrue so you can most accurately plan for a disaster.

\r\n\r\n

FEMA provides a Business Impact Analysis Worksheet you can distribute to management and any other employees you feel can contribute to your preparations. Download the worksheet here: http://www.ready.gov/sites/default/files/documents/files/BusinessImpactAnalysis_Worksheet.pdf

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

Some emergency action plans will cover problems dealing with hazardous materials on hand, some will need to deal with issues stemming from older buildings that were built to a lower-standard safety code, and some will need to have strategies in place to prepare for natural disasters more likely in certain areas, such as hurricanes, earthquakes, and tornadoes.

\n

While many things will be different depending on the type of emergency you are preparing forwhat you do during a tornado or earthquake will be much different than what you do during a fire or workplace violence incident, for examplesome of the basic preparations will be similar for multiple problems. Always provide steps for getting people to safety, whether that means sheltering or evacuating them, and always have a clear and effective plan for communicating with everyone who could be affected.

\n

Be sure to investigate not just what hazards you may face and how to stay safe during them, but also what effects they will have afterward. This should reveal such considerations as what lost income and increased expenses could be caused by your business being shut down for various amounts of time, the effect of lost customers, the delay of new business plans, and other effects of a disruption of service.   • For emergency situations, have an individual in charge of following and getting others to follow the procedures you outline. For larger companies, you may need more than one, in separate departments or as backups, but in this case make sure the hierarchy is clearly laid out.   • Ensure the methods for reporting fires and other emergencies are clear, whether it's dialing 911, calling an internal emergency number, pulling a manual fire alarm, or other procedure which may change depending on the type of emergency.

  • Have procedures in place for employees who must remain during the beginning of an evacuation to take care of greater hazards. " }, "description": "Rationale for why your workplace should have an Emergency Action Plan.", "image": { "UUID": "b302865b-6e06-44ab-91ce-7229de0490ad", "name": "isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg?itok=c2wu3JnG", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg" }, "body": [ { "id": 260, "uuid": "3c623628-2b4b-418b-8206-1bb86e31c13a", "revision_id": 582, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583857015, "parent_id": "226", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

\n" } }, { "id": 261, "uuid": "076bcddf-01f7-42b1-9a41-5f9910d0114b", "revision_id": 583, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583856683, "parent_id": "226", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_list_content": { "value": "
    \r\n\t
  • Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.
    • \r\n\t
  • Customers may not understand the disaster and its effects on your business. They'll still expect products or service on time. If there's a significant delay, they may take their business to a competitor.
    • \r\n\t
  • Even if a disaster does slow or shut down your business, a robust emergency action plan has procedures in place to contact customers and stakeholders quickly to keep them up to date on what has happened. News travels fast and perceptions are often different from reality. Staying on top of the information stream reduces negative perception.
    • \r\n\t
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \r\n\t
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \r\n\t
  • Many large businesses are now expecting their suppliers to have preparations in place for emergencies, trying to make sure their own business will not be hurt if something happens to another company on the supply chain. Without a plan in place, your business could be given to a competitor.
    • \r\n
\r\n", "format": "list", "processed": "
    \n
  • Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.
    • \n
  • Customers may not understand the disaster and its effects on your business. They'll still expect products or service on time. If there's a significant delay, they may take their business to a competitor.
    • \n
  • Even if a disaster does slow or shut down your business, a robust emergency action plan has procedures in place to contact customers and stakeholders quickly to keep them up to date on what has happened. News travels fast and perceptions are often different from reality. Staying on top of the information stream reduces negative perception.
    • \n
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \n
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \n
  • Many large businesses are now expecting their suppliers to have preparations in place for emergencies, trying to make sure their own business will not be hurt if something happens to another company on the supply chain. Without a plan in place, your business could be given to a competitor.

In this lesson, you will learn how to stay connected, find and organize the content relevant to you, and take advantage of pre-loaded content on working remotely.", "image": { "UUID": "8b68f317-73cb-4bc4-989d-4f54ce827669", "name": "SLgo_LearningObject_App.png", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/SLgo_LearningObject_App.png.jpg?itok=Vqpd89xU", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/SLgo_LearningObject_App.png" }, "body": [ { "id": 305, "uuid": "13d24610-77a0-435f-acf4-b47154f9598f", "revision_id": 867, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1584387127, "parent_id": "251", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": true, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

Connecting people. SLGO helps you learn when and where you want to and be able to pick up anywhere at any time. Your admin can deliver relevant content to you remotely and review your progress. This means you can stay connected and keep your knowledge up to date from the comfort of your home.

\r\n\r\n

Enhancing Productivity.  Effective learning can help to solve problems and accelerate performance. SLGO has learning content for all levels from exploring to studying, to sharpening. You can browse topics or join groups to find content tailored to you. We also have free courses from TorranceLearning.

\r\n\r\n

Giving you results. SLGO uses a powerful recommendation engine to give you content that reinforces what you are learning and bring similar lessons to your attention. As you complete courses and interact with flashcards, quizzes, and tip cards, you will receive meaningful feedback. 

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

request.description:
Retrieves content belonging to the group within the specified topic.

### Query parameters
* `title` - filter the response to content with a title containing the provided value
* `page` - retrieve a specific page

### Paging
This endpoint allows for paging with the `page` query parameter. Paging uses a 0-based index. For example, to request the second page, add `page=1` to the query parameters.

{ "rows": [ { "id": "0113f56c-e06b-4d21-b0db-688e74447834", "nid": 229, "vid": 519, "url": "/node/229", "name": "Did you know? 40% of Businesses Affected by Disaster Never Reopen. ", "type": "tip_card", "changed": "2020-03-18T19:24:07+0000", "is_promoted": false, "is_sticky": false, "file": null, "tags": [], "topic": { "id": "fb473dd7-86a8-40a6-8a12-c9c80d46c2fb", "vid": 80, "tid": 80, "url": "/taxonomy/term/80", "name": "Occupational Safety and Health", "type": "category", "changed": "2021-02-01T00:30:23+0000", "description": "This topic includes content related to the safety, health, and welfare of people at work The goal of occupational safety and health programs is to foster a safe and healthy work environment.[3] OSH may also protect co-workers, family members, employers, customers, and many others who might be affected by the workplace environment. " }, "contents": [ "
\n
\n
\n \n

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster but a good plan can keep your business safe as well. Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen.Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.

\n

\n
\n \n
\n
\n\n
\n", "
\n
\n
\n \n
\n\n\n
\n \n
\n
\n\n
\n" ], "body": [ { "id": "c548cc2f-d8f0-4a98-88f5-f96ae130d076", "type": "text", "fields": [ { "type": "Label", "attributes": { "Text": "

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster but a good plan can keep your business safe as well. Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.

\r\n\r\n

" }, "description": "A brief guide to creating an Emergency Action Plan", "image": { "UUID": "1f445741-9ed9-414f-8a60-68239e502915", "name": "emergency-plan.jpg", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg?itok=RG84ODJ3", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg" }, "body": [ { "id": 262, "uuid": "3c8cf7f3-6494-41aa-8844-60ffb4a8dca4", "revision_id": 595, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583858101, "parent_id": "227", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

How to Get Started

\r\n\r\n

The best time to handle an emergency is before it ever takes place. Before you create your emergency action plan, you'll need to analyze your business and see what potential hazards you face. These can vary depending on the type of business and your location. Some emergency action plans will cover problems dealing with hazardous materials on hand, some will need to deal with issues stemming from older buildings that were built to a lower-standard safety code, and some will need to have strategies in place to prepare for natural disasters more likely in certain areas, such as hurricanes, earthquakes, and tornadoes.

\r\n\r\n

While many things will be different depending on the type of emergency you are preparing forwhat you do during a tornado or earthquake will be much different than what you do during a fire or workplace violence incident, for examplesome of the basic preparations will be similar for multiple problems. Always provide steps for getting people to safety, whether that means sheltering or evacuating them, and always have a clear and effective plan for communicating with everyone who could be affected.

\r\n\r\n

Be sure to investigate not just what hazards you may face and how to stay safe during them, but also what effects they will have afterward. This should reveal such considerations as what lost income and increased expenses could be caused by your business being shut down for various amounts of time, the effect of lost customers, the delay of new business plans, and other effects of a disruption of service. Be as exact as possible in order to get a good idea of what costs you might accrue so you can most accurately plan for a disaster.

\r\n\r\n

FEMA provides a Business Impact Analysis Worksheet you can distribute to management and any other employees you feel can contribute to your preparations. Download the worksheet here: http://www.ready.gov/sites/default/files/documents/files/BusinessImpactAnalysis_Worksheet.pdf

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

Create Your Emergency Action Plan

\r\n\r\n

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

\n" } }, { "id": 261, "uuid": "076bcddf-01f7-42b1-9a41-5f9910d0114b", "revision_id": 583, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583856683, "parent_id": "226", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_list_content": { "value": "
    \r\n\t
  • Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.
    • \r\n\t
  • Customers may not understand the disaster and its effects on your business. They'll still expect products or service on time. If there's a significant delay, they may take their business to a competitor.
    • \r\n\t
  • Even if a disaster does slow or shut down your business, a robust emergency action plan has procedures in place to contact customers and stakeholders quickly to keep them up to date on what has happened. News travels fast and perceptions are often different from reality. Staying on top of the information stream reduces negative perception.
    • \r\n\t
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \r\n\t
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \r\n\t
  • Many large businesses are now expecting their suppliers to have preparations in place for emergencies, trying to make sure their own business will not be hurt if something happens to another company on the supply chain. Without a plan in place, your business could be given to a competitor.

    • \n
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \n
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \n

request.description:
Retrieve all group content, sorted by title.

### Query Parameters
* `title` - filter the response to content with a title containing the provided value
* `type` - filter the response to a specific type of content
* `page` - retrieve a specific page

### Content types
The following values are accepted in the `type` query parameter:
* `learn_article`
* `learn_link`
* `learn_package`
* `learn_file`
* `course`
* `flash_card`
* `tip_card`

### Paging
This endpoint allows for paging with the `page` query parameter. Paging uses a 0-based index. For example, to request the second page, add `page=1` to the query parameters.

" }, "description": "A brief guide to creating an Emergency Action Plan", "image": { "UUID": "1f445741-9ed9-414f-8a60-68239e502915", "name": "emergency-plan.jpg", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg?itok=RG84ODJ3", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/emergency-plan.jpg" }, "body": [ { "id": 262, "uuid": "3c8cf7f3-6494-41aa-8844-60ffb4a8dca4", "revision_id": 595, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583858101, "parent_id": "227", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

How to Get Started

\r\n\r\n

The best time to handle an emergency is before it ever takes place. Before you create your emergency action plan, you'll need to analyze your business and see what potential hazards you face. These can vary depending on the type of business and your location. Some emergency action plans will cover problems dealing with hazardous materials on hand, some will need to deal with issues stemming from older buildings that were built to a lower-standard safety code, and some will need to have strategies in place to prepare for natural disasters more likely in certain areas, such as hurricanes, earthquakes, and tornadoes.

\r\n\r\n

While many things will be different depending on the type of emergency you are preparing forwhat you do during a tornado or earthquake will be much different than what you do during a fire or workplace violence incident, for examplesome of the basic preparations will be similar for multiple problems. Always provide steps for getting people to safety, whether that means sheltering or evacuating them, and always have a clear and effective plan for communicating with everyone who could be affected.

\r\n\r\n

Be sure to investigate not just what hazards you may face and how to stay safe during them, but also what effects they will have afterward. This should reveal such considerations as what lost income and increased expenses could be caused by your business being shut down for various amounts of time, the effect of lost customers, the delay of new business plans, and other effects of a disruption of service. Be as exact as possible in order to get a good idea of what costs you might accrue so you can most accurately plan for a disaster.

\r\n\r\n

FEMA provides a Business Impact Analysis Worksheet you can distribute to management and any other employees you feel can contribute to your preparations. Download the worksheet here: http://www.ready.gov/sites/default/files/documents/files/BusinessImpactAnalysis_Worksheet.pdf

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

Create Your Emergency Action Plan

\r\n\r\n

Once you have identified all of the possible threats you may face and the potential effects, you should come up with responses for the hazards. Here are some tips to keep in mind.

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

    \r\n\t
  • For emergency situations, have an individual in charge of following and getting others to follow the procedures you outline. For larger companies, you may need more than one, in separate departments or as backups, but in this case make sure the hierarchy is clearly laid out. Employees must know this individual is in charge and has authority during an emergency.
    • \r\n\t
  • Ensure the methods for reporting fires and other emergencies are clear, whether it's dialing 911, calling an internal emergency number, pulling a manual fire alarm, or other procedure which may change depending on the type of emergency.
    • \r\n\t
  • Create evacuation policies and paths that are clear and easy to follow.
    • \r\n\t
  • Have procedures in place for employees who must remain during the beginning of an evacuation to take care of greater hazards. This includes employees who must use fire extinguishers, shut down gas lines and/or electrical systems, or safeguard hazardous materials to keep a bad situation from getting worse.
    • \r\n\t
  • Be prepared for the loss of computer hardware, software, and information related to technological disruptions, and find ways to back up and recover it.
    • \r\n\t
  • Note who is able to perform medical care, from first aid to CPR, and make sure they are in the proper positions to do so.
    • \r\n\t
  • Provide clear communication during and immediately after any dangerous incident.
    • \r\n

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster but a good plan can keep your business safe as well. Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen.Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.

Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.

" }, "description": "Rationale for why your workplace should have an Emergency Action Plan.", "image": { "UUID": "b302865b-6e06-44ab-91ce-7229de0490ad", "name": "isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg?itok=c2wu3JnG", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/isravel-raj-YuN8QjfBYUY-unsplash.jpg" }, "body": [ { "id": 260, "uuid": "3c623628-2b4b-418b-8206-1bb86e31c13a", "revision_id": 582, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583857015, "parent_id": "226", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

The main reason to have an emergency action plan is to do as much as possible to keep your employees safe in case of disaster. The confusion of an emergency can make a bad situation worse and put lives at risk. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) provides more reasons an emergency action plan is important from a purely business perspective.

\n" } }, { "id": 261, "uuid": "076bcddf-01f7-42b1-9a41-5f9910d0114b", "revision_id": 583, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1583856683, "parent_id": "226", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": false, "field_list_content": { "value": "
    \r\n\t
  • Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.
    • \r\n\t
  • Customers may not understand the disaster and its effects on your business. They'll still expect products or service on time. If there's a significant delay, they may take their business to a competitor.
    • \r\n\t
  • Even if a disaster does slow or shut down your business, a robust emergency action plan has procedures in place to contact customers and stakeholders quickly to keep them up to date on what has happened. News travels fast and perceptions are often different from reality. Staying on top of the information stream reduces negative perception.
    • \r\n\t
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \r\n\t
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \r\n\t
  • Many large businesses are now expecting their suppliers to have preparations in place for emergencies, trying to make sure their own business will not be hurt if something happens to another company on the supply chain. Without a plan in place, your business could be given to a competitor.
    • \r\n
\r\n", "format": "list", "processed": "
    \n
  • Up to 40% of businesses affected by a natural or human-caused disaster never reopen. Having procedures in place to deal with disasters can help your business survive this difficult experience.
    • \n
  • Customers may not understand the disaster and its effects on your business. They'll still expect products or service on time. If there's a significant delay, they may take their business to a competitor.
    • \n
  • Even if a disaster does slow or shut down your business, a robust emergency action plan has procedures in place to contact customers and stakeholders quickly to keep them up to date on what has happened. News travels fast and perceptions are often different from reality. Staying on top of the information stream reduces negative perception.
    • \n
  • Insurance often only provides partial assistance. It does not cover all losses and does not bring back lost customers.
    • \n
  • Public agencies cannot be expected to provide total relief either. Many disasters can overwhelm their resources, meaning aid may not be immediate even when it is available.
    • \n
  • Many large businesses are now expecting their suppliers to have preparations in place for emergencies, trying to make sure their own business will not be hurt if something happens to another company on the supply chain. Without a plan in place, your business could be given to a competitor.
    • \n

In this lesson, you will learn how to stay connected, find and organize the content relevant to you, and take advantage of pre-loaded content on working remotely.", "image": { "UUID": "8b68f317-73cb-4bc4-989d-4f54ce827669", "name": "SLgo_LearningObject_App.png", "url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/styles/large/public/2020-03/SLgo_LearningObject_App.png.jpg?itok=Vqpd89xU", "original_url": "http://perls.localhost:8000/sites/default/files/2020-03/SLgo_LearningObject_App.png" }, "body": [ { "id": 305, "uuid": "13d24610-77a0-435f-acf4-b47154f9598f", "revision_id": 867, "langcode": "en", "type": null, "status": true, "created": 1584387127, "parent_id": "251", "parent_type": "node", "parent_field_name": "field_body", "behavior_settings": [], "default_langcode": true, "revision_translation_affected": true, "field_paragraph_body": { "value": "

Connecting people. SLGO helps you learn when and where you want to and be able to pick up anywhere at any time. Your admin can deliver relevant content to you remotely and review your progress. This means you can stay connected and keep your knowledge up to date from the comfort of your home.

\r\n\r\n

Enhancing Productivity.  Effective learning can help to solve problems and accelerate performance. SLGO has learning content for all levels from exploring to studying, to sharpening. You can browse topics or join groups to find content tailored to you. We also have free courses from TorranceLearning.

\r\n\r\n

Giving you results. SLGO uses a powerful recommendation engine to give you content that reinforces what you are learning and bring similar lessons to your attention. As you complete courses and interact with flashcards, quizzes, and tip cards, you will receive meaningful feedback. 

\r\n", "format": "inline_styling", "processed": "

request.description:
Add new Web link content

The response is a new web link node record

### Link destination(link\_type)

This decides whether the URL is stored under

*   `web` - a http/https URL for web content.
*   `custom` - URL for native content/asset with scheme prefix.
    

### Response codes

*   `201` - The web link was created
*   `403` - The user is not allowed to create web link content
*   `422` - Un-processable Entity: The mandatory fields Title(name)/ Topic(topic) is empty or missing
